tweets.text: Many judges had broken the law

quoted.text:
üö®üá∫üá∏ BREAKING: WISCONSIN JUDGE CONVICTED OF FELONY FOR HELPING ILLEGAL IMMIGRANT EVADE ICE ARREST

"I'll do it. I'll get the heat."

She got it.

Milwaukee County Judge Hannah Dugan was convicted Thursday of obstructing an official proceeding, a felony carrying up to five years in prison.

She was acquitted of a misdemeanor charge.

The facts: In April, FBI and ICE agents arrived at Dugan's courthouse to arrest Eduardo Flores Ruiz, who had been deported in 2013 and was back in the country illegally facing battery charges.

Dugan sent the agents down the hall to another office. 

While they were away, she postponed Flores Ruiz's hearing and personally directed him out a back door.

Prosecutors played a recording of Dugan telling her court reporter about the plan. 

When her clerk asked if she should show the immigrant the exit, Dugan replied: 

"I'll do it. I'll get the heat."

Agents chased Flores Ruiz on foot and arrested him outside. 

He was deported in November.

Dugan, 66, will lose her judgeship. 

Wisconsin's constitution bars convicted felons from holding public office.

Prosecutor Kelly Brown Watzka: 

"She was a frustrated and angry judge who was fed up, who decided to corruptly take matters into her own hands."

The message is clear: no one is above immigration law. Not even judges.

Source: Washington Post

tweets.text:
RT @MarioNawfal: ELON: ANYONE CAN LOOK GENEROUS. DOING REAL GOOD IS RARE

Elon gave an amazing assessment about giving away money being far‚Ä¶

retweet.text:
ELON: ANYONE CAN LOOK GENEROUS. DOING REAL GOOD IS RARE

Elon gave an amazing assessment about giving away money being far more complicated than it looks, especially if the goal is real impact instead of public praise. 

He said the appearance of goodness is easy to buy, but the reality of goodness is not, which is why he keeps his foundation quiet and avoids putting his name on projects. 

According to Elon, the real challenge is making sure money actually helps people rather than just signaling virtue. 

It is a rare admission in a world where philanthropy is often treated like branding:

‚ÄúI agree with love of humanity and trying to help our fellow human beings. 

But if you care about the reality of goodness rather than the perception of it, it is very difficult to give away money. 

I have a large foundation, but I don‚Äôt put my name on it. 

The biggest challenge is giving money away in a way that is truly beneficial. 

It is easy to give money away for the appearance of goodness. 

It is very difficult to give money away for the reality of goodness.‚Äù

Source: @nikhilkamathcio @elonmusk

tweets.text: RT @ArtemisConsort: There is no good evidence that transition improves mental health outcomes, in children or adults. Most studies claiming‚Ä¶

retweet.text:
There is no good evidence that transition improves mental health outcomes, in children or adults. Most studies claiming to show otherwise are methodological train wrecks, and these same people would be pointing that out if their results didn‚Äôt support the narrative.

There is a strong negative correlation between study quality and observed effect of transition on mental health. When proper controls are present, the studies are longitudinal over a substantial period, and we look at objective measures of mental health like psychiatric hospital visits and suicide attempts rather than self-reports, we see insignificant or even negative effects.

Thousands of parents were told some version of ‚Äúyou can have a dead son or living daughter‚Äù by medical professionals they trusted, when there was never a good reason to think this is true. It‚Äôs a lie on an almost unimaginable scale. It‚Äôs so monstrous that it‚Äôs hard to face. But we must face it.
